title: Mixed race couple in Lidl ad flee their home after racial abuse and death threats
text:

A mixed-race couple say they have been forced to leave Ireland after receiving abuse online and even death threats against their toddler son after appearing in Lidl ad.

Fiona Ryan, 33, and her fiance Jonathan Mathis, 32, have been targeted by abuse since they appeared in an ad campaign for the supermarket chain along with their 22-month-old boy.

The family's inclusion in the ads, which began appearing on billboards and TV in Ireland in early September, saw the couple targeted in an online campaign to boycott Lidl.

Ms Ryan told RTE's Late Late Show on Friday night the family had decided to move to England after receiving abusive and racist comments online - including a death threat directed at their toddler, the Irish Times reports.

She said online abusers were writing vitriol about them on Facebook and Twitter and trying to contact their accounts.

(Image: Lidl)

She told the programme: “They are talking about harming and death to my partner and my child so I am not going to stay in a country [where] this is allowed.”

Mr Mathis is originally from Brazil but grew up in England, in Liverpool and the Cotswolds before moving to Ireland with his love.

He said he has fielded hateful comments because of his skin colour throughout his life before to the point where it seemed "normal" to him, and was disgusted to see the reaction to the advertisement.

“I got so upset and angry at the same time. These people are looking at my child and saying all this hurtful stuff. He’s a completely innocent child.”

(Image: Getty Images)

Lidl Ireland early last month tweeted that it was having to block and report "offensive and racist tweets" from former journalist Gemma O'Doherty about the couple's inclusion in the ad.

The prominent provocateur, who is widely described in Irish media as a conspiracy theorist, began whipping up an online campaign to boycott Lidl after seeing the ads featuring the family.

During the programme's presenter Ryan Tubridy read out a comment about the couple posted on Twitter by Ms O’Doherty.

She wrote: “German dump @lidl_ireland gaslighting the Irish people with their multicultural version of ‘The Ryans’. Kidding no-one! Resist the Great Replacement wherever you can by giving this kip a wide berth. #ShopIrish #BuyIrish.”

(Image: AFP via Getty Images)

The tweet reportedly attracted a slew of vile responses - including comments from Twitter users about "race/ancestor betrayal," and replies attacking immigrants and "Africans".

Ireland's Prime Minister Leo Varadkar condemned the abuse.

The leader of the government called the social media attacks on the County Meath couple "disgusting".

Ms Ryan, who is from Ireland originally and is an actor, earlier told Newstalk she moved to London when she was 19 and met Mr Mathis, a construction worker, seven years ago.

The couple decided to move back to Ireland together last year after travelling, and settled down to have baby Jonah.

She told media the abuse was centred on the couple's multicultural relationship, with trolls accusing them of not representing "real" Irish families.

Lidl Ireland tweeted on September 8: "We are proud of our multicultural & diverse team and our customers. We are proud to work with, and serve, each and every one of them. Everyone is welcome in our store."

Ms O'Doherty later labelled reports on the abuse targeting the couple and the ad "fake news" and "hysteria."

The couple criticised Ireland's police force, as well as Facebook and Twitter, saying none of them had done enough to crackdown on the family's online abusers- despite their concerns their toddler was a target.

After the couple reported the matter to the Garda the force reportedly told the couple it was a civil matter.

The couple has previously said they bore no ill-will towards Ms O'Doherty, saying she had actually done them a favour by highlighting a weakness in hate crime legislation in Ireland.

In order to report the hate speech the couple were being forced to search for and read abusive tweets about themselves to collect evidence.
description: Fiona Ryan and Jonathan Mathis have been been subject to vile racist abuse since they featured in an ad campaign for Lidl with their baby boy
